questions.text: All of the following can be administrated in acute hypertesion during labour except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) labetalol or hydralazine administered intravenously as a first-line agent for acute therapy of severe hypertension. Nimodipine, diazoxide, and ketanserin are best avoided. If labetalol alone is ineffective, we suggest switching to hydralazine. Alternatively, intravenous nicardipine or oral nifedipine can be used. The following drugs are not used in pregnancy for hypertension due to potential fetal harm: 1. ACE inhibitors (e.g., Enalapril, Ramipril). 2. ARBs (e.g., Losartan, Valsartan). 3. Direct renin inhibitors (e.g., Aliskiren). 4. Certain diuretics and beta-blockers (e.g., Atenolol). 5. Sodium nitroprusside. 6. Diazoxide These drugs are replaced with safer alternatives like labetalol, methyldopa, nifedipine, and hydralazine.

questions.text: In pregnant female with BP 150/100 mm hg, a protien/creatinine ratio of _____ suggests development of pre-eclampsia:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In patients with gestational hypertension , ther are high chances(15-25%) of progressing to pre-eclampsia. Pre-eclampsia is heralded by the development of proteinuria. Protein/creatinine ratio= >0.30 indicates pre-eclampsia Diagnostic Criteria 1. Proteinuria Thresholds: • ?300 mg/24-hour urine collection: Gold standard for diagnosing proteinuria in preeclampsia. • Spot Urine Protein-to-Creatinine Ratio (PCR) ?0.3: A convenient and reliable alternative to 24-hour urine collection. • Dipstick Urine Test: • ?2+ on a random urine sample: Suggests proteinuria, but less reliable compared to quantitative methods. Proteinuria is not mandatory for the diagnosis of preeclampsia if other severe features are present, such as: • Severe hypertension (?160/110 mmHg). • Thrombocytopenia (platelets 1.1 mg/dL). • Pulmonary edema. • Persistent cerebral or visual disturbances. 2. Timing: • Proteinuria must occur after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive woman with new-onset hypertension. 3. Exclusion of Other Causes: • Ensure proteinuria is not due to underlying renal disease, urinary tract infection, or other pre-existing conditions.

questions.text: Recurrence rate of HELLP syndrome:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Recurrence rate is upto 7% Recurrence rate of HELLP syndrome The recurrence risk of HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelets) in subsequent pregnancies is approximately 5-7%. This means that while the majority of women who experience HELLP syndrome in one pregnancy do not develop it in subsequent pregnancies, there remains a small but significant risk of recurrence. Low-dose aspirin (75–150 mg/day) started before 16 weeks gestation is recommended for women at high risk of preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome. The diagnosis of HELLP syndrome is based on laboratory findings: 1. Hemolysis: • Abnormal peripheral blood smear: Schistocytes or fragmented red blood cells. • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) >600 IU/L. • Low haptoglobin levels. 2. Elevated Liver Enzymes: • Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) >70 IU/L. • Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) may also be elevated. 3. Low Platelet Count: • Platelet count <100,000/µL.

questions.text: Pre-eclampsia M/C presents in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Preeclampsia most commonly occurs in the third trimester because of increasing placental demands and maternal circulatory stress. Timing of Onset • Early-Onset Preeclampsia: • Develops before 34 weeks of gestation. • Associated with more severe complications and higher risks for both the mother and fetus. • Often linked to underlying placental abnormalities. • Late-Onset Preeclampsia: • Develops at 34 weeks or later. • More common and generally less severe. • Often associated with maternal cardiovascular or metabolic conditions. Clinical Implications • Maternal Risk: • End-organ damage, including kidney injury, liver dysfunction, and neurological complications like eclampsia. • Fetal Risk: • Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). • Premature delivery. • Placental abruption.

questions.text: DOC for PIH is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The answer to the question should have been Labetatol. But since it is not given in options we will go with alpha methyldopa. Methyldopa is used for chronic hypertension in pregnancy and mild pre-eclampsia but is not used in severe pre-eclampsia because of delayed onset of action. Preeclampsia Management: 1. Labetalol: • First-line for moderate to severe hypertension in pregnancy. • A combined alpha- and beta-blocker that is safe for both the mother and fetus. 2. Nifedipine: • A calcium channel blocker that is another effective first-line agent. • Often used for acute management of severe hypertension. 3. Hydralazine: • Reserved for acute management of severe hypertension in preeclampsia. • Administered intravenously in hypertensive emergencies. 4. Magnesium Sulfate: • Not an antihypertensive but is the drug of choice for seizure prophylaxis in preeclampsia and treatment of eclampsia. Since labetalol is not in options hence answer is methyldopa Alpha-Methyldopa is the drug for treating mild chronic hypertension in pregnancy and mild to moderate preeclampsia. It is a centrally acting antihypertensive that lowers blood pressure by reducing sympathetic outflow from the central nervous system, making it safe and effective for use during pregnancy. It has been extensively studied and has a long history of safety for both the mother and fetus.

questions.text: A 27 year primigravida presents with pregnancy induced hypertion with blood pressure of 150/ 100mm of Hg at 32 weeks of gstation with no othet complications,. Subsequently, her blood pressure is controlled on treatment . If there are no complication, the pregnancy should be terminated at:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The patient in the question has BP=150/100mm of Hg,i.e mild hypertensionand has no complications. Her BP is controlled on Treatment ,i,e. she is being managed expectantly. In such patients pregnancy should be terminated at 37 weeks Why Delivery at 37 Weeks is Ideal 1. Maternal Safety: • Preeclampsia is a progressive condition that can lead to severe complications such as eclampsia, HELLP syndrome, placental abruption, and maternal organ failure. • Delivering at 37 weeks minimizes these risks without significantly increasing the risk of neonatal complications. 2. Fetal Maturity: • By 37 weeks, the fetus is considered term, with fully developed lungs and a lower risk of neonatal complications like respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). • The risk of intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) or stillbirth increases as preeclampsia progresses, making delivery the safest option at this point. 3. Guidelines: • The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and other international guidelines recommend delivery at 37 weeks for women with mild preeclampsia or gestational hypertension. • For women with severe preeclampsia, delivery is recommended earlier, depending on the severity and gestational age. When to Deliver Before 37 Weeks Early delivery (<37 weeks) is indicated in cases of severe preeclampsia with maternal or fetal complications: • Maternal Indications: • Severe hypertension unresponsive to treatment. • Neurological symptoms (e.g., severe headache, visual disturbances). • HELLP syndrome. • Pulmonary edema or acute kidney injury. • Fetal Indications: • Severe IUGR. • Non-reassuring fetal heart patterns. • Oligohydramnios or abnormal Doppler studies. In such cases, antenatal corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone) are given to promote fetal lung maturity if delivery occurs before 34 weeks.

questions.text: Risk factors for preeclampsia:(PGI TYPE)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B, C and E) Risk Factors for Preeclampsia Primigravida: Young or elderly (fi rst time exposure to chorionic villi) Family history: Hypertension, preeclampsia Placental abnormalities: Hyperplacentosis: Excessive exposure to chorionic villi—(molar pregnancy twins, diabetes) Placental ischemia. Obesity: BMI >35 kg/m2, Insulin resistance. Pre-existing vascular disease Thrombophilias [antiphospholipid syndrome, protein C, S defi ciency, Factor V Leiden Hence answer here is A B C E ( Ref dutta textbook of obstetrics/8th edition/256)

questions.text: Indicator of severe pre-eclampsia all are except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Features of severe PE are : Presence of EOD that can be indicated by : - Platelet count twice Evidence of serum creatinine >1.1 Pulmonary edema Cerebral/visual symptoms BP > 160/110 MM OF HG on 2 occasions 2 hours apart Hence answer here is option A. IUGR and Severe Preeclampsia Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR) is not a diagnostic criterion for severe preeclampsia, but it is often associated with the condition due to placental insufficiency. While IUGR indicates potential fetal compromise, the diagnosis of severe preeclampsia is based on maternal signs, symptoms, and laboratory findings rather than fetal growth parameters. Criteria for Severe Preeclampsia According to guidelines (e.g., ACOG), severe preeclampsia is defined by the presence of any one of the following: 1. Severe Hypertension: • Systolic blood pressure (SBP) ?160 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure (DBP) ?110 mmHg, measured twice at least 4 hours apart. 2. Thrombocytopenia: • Platelet count 1.1 mg/dL or doubling of baseline creatinine in the absence of other renal disease. 4. Liver Dysfunction: • Elevated liver enzymes (e.g., AST or ALT levels ?2 times the upper normal limit) or severe right upper quadrant/epigastric pain unresponsive to medication. 5. Pulmonary Edema: • Presence of fluid accumulation in the lungs. 6. Neurological Symptoms: • Persistent severe headache, visual disturbances (e.g., blurred vision, scotomata), or eclampsia. Role of IUGR in Preeclampsia • IUGR is a complication of placental insufficiency caused by preeclampsia. • While it signals fetal compromise and the severity of placental dysfunction, it is not a defining criterion for diagnosing severe preeclampsia. • IUGR in preeclampsia is an indication for closer fetal monitoring and may influence the timing of delivery.

choices.text: Increase in systolic BP by 30 mm Hg and diastolic by 15 mm Hg

questions.text: All of the following indicate superimposed pre-eclampsia in a pregnant female of chronic hypertension except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) To diagnose superimposed preeclampsia, a woman with chronic hypertension must meet one or more of the following criteria: 1. New-Onset Proteinuria • Proteinuria develops after 20 weeks of gestation in a woman who did not previously have proteinuria. • Defined as: • ?300 mg/24-hour urine collection. • Protein-to-creatinine ratio (PCR) ?0.3. • ?2+ on urine dipstick (less reliable). 2. Sudden Worsening of Pre-Existing Proteinuria • If proteinuria was present before 20 weeks (due to chronic kidney disease or pre-existing hypertension), a sudden and significant increase in proteinuria indicates superimposed preeclampsia. 3. Severe Hypertension • New or worsening hypertension: • Systolic blood pressure (SBP) ?160 mmHg. • Diastolic blood pressure (DBP) ?110 mmHg. • Persistent even after appropriate treatment. 4. New Signs of End-Organ Damage • Thrombocytopenia: Platelets 1.1 mg/dL. • Doubling of serum creatinine from baseline. • Liver Dysfunction: • Elevated liver enzymes (AST or ALT ?2 times the upper limit of normal). • Severe right upper quadrant or epigastric pain. • Neurological Symptoms: • Persistent severe headache or visual disturbances (e.g., blurred vision, scotomata). • Pulmonary Edema: • Signs of fluid accumulation in the lungs.

choices.text: Admit the patient, start antihypertensive and continue pregnancy till term.
Admit the patient, start antihypertensive, mg SO4 and terminate the pregnancy
Admit oral antihypertensives and follow up in outpatient department

questions.text: A female of 36 weeks gestation presents with hypertension, blurring of vision and headache. Her blood pressure reading was 180/120 mm Hg and 174/110 mm Hg after 20 minutes. How will you manage the patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Signs of impending eclampsia are : Epigastric pain due to subcapsular hematoma Headache / dizziness due to cerebral hypoxia) Blurring of vision due to hypertensive retinopathy ( diplopia / scotoma/blindness) Blindness is due to hypoxic injury to occipital lobe Here patient is of impending eclampsia Best management in patients of impending eclampsia – admit the patient Start antihypertensive drugs indication for antihypertensive are >160/110mm of hg labetalol is DOC in pregnancy Iv Mgso4 is started to prevent chances of seizures. It acts as a membrane stabilizer and neuroprotector. Next step is termination of pregnancy – all the patients of Gest HTN and mild pre eclampsia should be delivered by 37 weeks while those of severe PE should be delivered by 34 weeks

questions.text: A 28 year old eclamptic woman develop convulsions. The first measure to be done is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Measures in case of eclampsia : Call for extra help (Communication) To put patient in left lateral recumbent position Maintain oral airway t O2 inhalation – nonbreather mask; 10 L/minute Commence IV lines; 1 or 2 wide bore cannulas Foley catheter with urometer t To monitor O2 saturation; pulse oximeter (SPO2 > 95%) Control of seizures: MgSO4, (IV/IM regimens) First Measure in the Management of Eclampsia The first and most critical measure in the management of eclampsia (the occurrence of seizures in a woman with preeclampsia) is to: 1. Stabilize the Airway, Breathing, and Circulation (ABC Approach) • Airway: • Ensure the airway is patent to prevent aspiration and maintain oxygenation. • Position the patient in the left lateral position to reduce the risk of aspiration and improve venous return. • Breathing: • Administer oxygen via mask if oxygen saturation is low (12/min), and urine output (>30 mL/hour). 3. Control Severe Hypertension • Use antihypertensive medications to reduce blood pressure and prevent complications like stroke: • Labetalol: 20 mg IV bolus, repeated every 10–20 minutes (up to 300 mg total). • Hydralazine: 5–10 mg IV bolus every 20 minutes as needed. • Nifedipine: 10–20 mg orally every 20–30 minutes. 4. Plan for Delivery • Delivery is the definitive treatment for eclampsia and preeclampsia. • Once the patient is stabilized, assess maternal and fetal conditions to determine the safest mode and timing of delivery. • If the fetus is viable and the maternal condition allows, vaginal delivery is preferred. • Cesarean section is indicated if rapid delivery is needed or vaginal delivery is contraindicated.

questions.text: Which is not a feature of HELLP syndrome:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) HELLP syndrome denotes : Hemolysis Elevated liver enzymes ( AST > 70 IU ) Low platelets ( < 1 lakh ) Other features are : presence of schistiocytes (HELMET CELLS ) and total bilirubin > 1.2

questions.text: All are true about pre eclampsia except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Abnormal weight gain Rise of blood pressure: The diastolic pressure usually tends to rise first followed by the systolic pressure. This can cause manifestation like cerebral hemorrahege Edema: Sudden and generalized edema may indicate imminent eclampsia. Pulmonary edema—due to leaky capillaries and low oncotic pressure. ARF can also been seen in cases of pre eclampsia Abdominal examination may reveal evidences of chronic placental insufficiency, such as scanty liquor or growth retardation of the fetus. Thus, the manifestations of preeclampsia usually appear in the following order—rapid gain in weight → visible edema and/or hypertension → proteinuria

questions.text: Concentration of MgSO4 in the treatment of eclampsia in meq/L:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Concentration of Mgso4 is : Intramuscular (Pritchard regimen ) : 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 minute followed by 10 g (50%), deep IM (5 gm in each buttock) Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4–6 g IV slow over 15–20 minutues The therapeutic level of serum magnesium is 4–7 mEQ/L( Ref dutta textbook of obstetrics/ 8TH edition/273 ) Magnesium Sulfate (MgSO?) Therapeutic Levels The therapeutic serum level of magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis and treatment in eclampsia is: 4–7 mEq/L (or 2–3.5 mmol/L) Details of Therapeutic Levels • Therapeutic Range: • Maintains seizure control while minimizing the risk of toxicity. • Toxic Levels: • Loss of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs): >7 mEq/L (or >3.5 mmol/L). • Respiratory depression: >12mEq/L (or >5 mmol/L). • Cardiac arrest: >15 -20 mEq/L (or >7.5 mmol/L). Monitoring Parameters To ensure magnesium levels stay within the therapeutic range, regular clinical and laboratory monitoring is essential: 1. Clinical Signs: • Deep tendon reflexes (DTRs): The first clinical indicator of magnesium toxicity is the loss of reflexes. • Respiratory rate: Should remain >12 breaths/min. • Urine output: >30 mL/hour is necessary to prevent magnesium accumulation. 2. Serum Magnesium Levels: • Periodic measurement of serum magnesium is performed in cases of clinical toxicity is suspected. Management of Toxicity If magnesium toxicity occurs: 1. Stop magnesium sulfate infusion immediately. 2. Administer calcium gluconate (10 mL of 10% solution IV over 10 minutes) as the antidote.

questions.text: Earliest sign of Mg toxicity:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Monitoring of Magnesium Toxicity Loss of deep tendon reflexes Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per minute) Urine output (< 30 mL/h) Chest pain, heart block Early signs: Loss of deep tendon reflexes. • Moderate signs: Respiratory depression. • Severe signs: Cardiac arrest and CNS depression. • Prompt recognition and treatment with calcium gluconate can prevent complications. Regular monitoring of clinical signs and magnesium levels is essential to ensure patient safety.

questions.text: Best drug for management of eclampsia:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Magnesium sulfate is the drug of choice. It acts as a membrane stabilizer and neuroprotector. It reduces motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine. Magnesium also blocks neuronal calcium influx. It induces cerebral vasodilatation, dilates uterine arteries, increases production of endothelial prostacyclin and inhibits platelet activation Compared to other regimes, magnesium sulfate has got the following benefits: It controls fits effectively without any depression effect to the mother or the infant. reduced risk of recurrent convulsions (9%) Significantly reduced maternal death rate (3%) and Reduced perinatal mortality rate.

choices.text: Induce labor after doing Bischop score
Initial inpatient evaluation followed by restricted activity and outpatient management.

questions.text: A 32-year old G3P2 woman at 35 weeks gestation has a past medical history significant for hypertension. She was well-controlled on hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril as an outpatient, but these drugs were discontinued when she found out that she was pregnant. Her blood pressure has been relatively well controlled in the 120-130 mm hg systolic range without medication, and urinalysis has consistently been negative for proteinuria at each of her prenatal visits she pressure of 142/84 mm Hg. A 24-hour urine specimen yields 0.35 g of proteinuria. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Here the patient is ELDERLY female having presence of hypertension of any cause antedating or before the 20th week of pregnancy hence diagnosis here is CHRONIC HYPERTENSION And in : In mild cases with blood pressure less than 160/100 mm Hg, adequate rest (physical and mental), low-salt diet are all that are needed. The check up should be more frequent 1–2 weeks interval up to 28 weeks and thereafter weekly If it is unclear whether the hypertension is gestational, chronic, or associated with preeclampsia, inpatient monitoring may be necessary for observation and workup. Inpatient Evaluation Components 1. Maternal Monitoring • Serial Blood Pressure Measurements: Monitored every 15–30 minutes if severe. • Urine Protein Assessment: • 24-hour urine collection for protein ?300 mg. • Protein-to-creatinine ratio (PCR) ?0.3. • Laboratory Tests: • Complete blood count (CBC) with platelets. • Liver function tests (LFTs). • Serum creatinine and uric acid. • Coagulation profile if HELLP syndrome is suspected. 2. Fetal Monitoring • Non-Stress Test (NST): To evaluate fetal heart rate patterns. • Ultrasound: • Assess fetal growth and amniotic fluid volume. • Doppler studies of the umbilical artery to check placental perfusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a predictive test for preeclampsia ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ischemic trophoblast, which is a characteristic finding in preeclampsia, increases production of anti-angiogenic proteins (sEng, sFlt1) and reduces production of angiogenic proteins (VEGF, PlGF) Two types of uterine artery Doppler waveform analysis techniques have emerged for prediction of preeclampsia, as well as other disorders associated with impaired placentation (eg, fetal growth restriction, pregnancy loss): (1) presence or absence of diastolic notching (unilateral, bilateral) of the uterine arcuate vessels and (2) flow waveform ratios (eg, high resistance or pulsatility index, systolic/diastolic ratio American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommendations for taking a detailed medical history to assess a patient's risks for developing preeclampsia but not using laboratory and imaging screening tests (including uterine artery Doppler velocimetry and serum biomarkers such as pro- and anti-angiogenic factors) Predictive Tests for Preeclampsia Preeclampsia is a significant cause of maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality. Predictive tests aim to identify women at high risk for developing preeclampsia early in pregnancy, allowing for preventive measures such as low-dose aspirin to be initiated. 1. Biochemical Tests a) Placental Growth Factor (PlGF) • What It Measures: Proangiogenic protein produced by the placenta. • Significance: Low levels of PlGF are associated with impaired placentation, a hallmark of preeclampsia. • When Used: Between 11–14 weeks or in the second trimester to assess risk. • Role: High negative predictive value for ruling out preeclampsia. b) Soluble fms-Like Tyrosine Kinase-1 (sFlt-1) • What It Measures: Antiangiogenic factor that binds PlGF and VEGF. • Significance: Elevated sFlt-1 levels are associated with endothelial dysfunction and preeclampsia. • Role: Used in combination with PlGF to calculate the sFlt-1/PlGF ratio. c) sFlt-1/PlGF Ratio • What It Indicates: Imbalance between angiogenic and antiangiogenic factors. • Significance: • Low Ratio: Rules out preeclampsia. • High Ratio: Indicates a higher risk of developing preeclampsia. • Timing: Effective in the second and third trimesters to predict short-term risk. 2. Biophysical Tests a) Uterine Artery Doppler • What It Measures: Resistance to blood flow in uterine arteries. • Significance: • Increased pulsatility index (PI) or the presence of diastolic notching suggests impaired placental perfusion and increased risk of preeclampsia. • Timing: Most effective when performed between 11–14 weeks of gestation. • Combination: More predictive when combined with biochemical markers. 3. Combined Screening (Most Predictive) • First-Trimester Screening: • Combines maternal risk factors (e.g., history of preeclampsia, chronic hypertension, BMI) with: • Biochemical Markers (PlGF). • Biophysical Markers (Uterine artery Doppler pulsatility index). • Results are integrated using algorithms to calculate a woman’s overall risk of developing preeclampsia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with 36 weeks of pregnancy, suddenly complains of headache and blurring of vision. Her B.P. is 170/110 mm of Hg. Urinary albumin is +++ and fundus examination shows areas of retinal hemorrhage. The line of further management would be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sudden headache and blurring of vision are signs of impending eclampsia and other featrures like bp > 160/110 and presence of proteinuria > 1 + also supports the diagnosis so such patients can throw fits at any point of time so anticonvulsive theraphy is treatment of choice and mgso4 Magnesium sulfate is the drug of choice for eclampsia . It acts as a membrane stabilizer and neuroprotector. It reduces motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine. Magnesium also blocks neuronal calcium influx. Hence prevent convulsion during labor. Impending eclampsia refers to a condition where a pregnant woman with severe preeclampsia shows signs and symptoms suggestive of an imminent seizure. Early recognition and prompt management are crucial to prevent progression to eclampsia. Clinical Features of Impending Eclampsia • Severe, persistent headache unresponsive to medication. • Visual disturbances (e.g., blurred vision, scotomata, photophobia). • Epigastric pain or right upper quadrant pain (indicative of liver involvement). • Nausea, vomiting, or restlessness. Stepwise Management 1. Admit the Patient • Immediate inpatient care in a high-dependency or intensive care unit (if available). • Continuous maternal and fetal monitoring. 2. Seizure Prophylaxis with Magnesium Sulfate • Magnesium sulfate is the drug of choice to prevent seizures. • Loading Dose: 4g IV over 15–20 minutes and 10 gm I/m • Maintenance Dose 5gm I/m for at least 24 hours after stabilization or delivery. • Monitor for toxicity: • Deep tendon reflexes (DTRs). • Respiratory rate >12/min. • Urine output >30 mL/hour. • Antidote for toxicity: Calcium gluconate (10 mL of 10% solution IV). 3. Control Severe Hypertension • Antihypertensive therapy is critical to prevent maternal complications such as stroke or placental abruption. • Labetalol: • IV bolus: 20 mg, repeat every 10–20 minutes if needed. • Oral: 200–400 mg every 12 hours for ongoing control. • Nifedipine: • Oral: 10–20 mg every 20 minutes (up to 3 doses). • Hydralazine: • IV: 5–10 mg every 20 minutes as needed. 4. Plan for Delivery (Definitive Treatment) • Delivery is the only definitive treatment for preeclampsia and impending eclampsia. • Timing: • Stabilize maternal condition first, unless immediate delivery is needed for severe maternal or fetal indications. • Aim for delivery within 24–48 hours. • Mode of Delivery: • Vaginal delivery is preferred if the cervix is favorable and maternal and fetal conditions allow. • Cesarean delivery is indicated for obstetric reasons or maternal/fetal instability.

choices.text: Cerebral anoxia due to arterial spasm

questions.text: Cause of convulsion in eclampsia:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CAUSE OF CONVULSION: Anoxia — spasm of the cerebral vessels → increased cerebral vascular resistance → fall in cerebral oxygen consumption → anoxia, Cerebral edema — may contribute to irritation, Cerebral dysrhythmia — increases following anoxia or edema. There is excessive release of excitatory neurotransmitters (glutamate).

questions.text: A 20-year-old G1 at 32 weeks presents for her routine obstetric (OB) visit. She has no medical problems. She is noted to have a blood pressure of 150/96 mm Hg, and her urine dip shows 2+ protein. She complains of a constant headache and vision changes that are not relieved with rest or a pain reliever. The patient is sent to the hospital for further management. At the hospital, her blood pressure is 158/98 mm Hg and she is noted to have tonic-clonic seizure. Which of the following is indicated in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Eclampsia is the presence of new-onset grand mal seizures in a woman with preeclampsia. She requires delivery. Cesarean delivery is not always necessary. Magnesium sulfate is given for prophylaxis against recurrent seizure. Magnesium sulfate has been shown in randomized control trials to be better than phenytoin or diazepam at preventing seizures. Low-dose aspirin and calcium supplementation have not been shown to be beneficial in preventing preeclampsia. Women with eclampsia should be stabilized quickly; magnesium sulfate should be started to prevent further seizures; and antihypertensives should be used to control blood pressure. The patient should be delivered in a timely fashion, and the method of delivery should depend on factors such as gestational age, fetal presentation, and cervical examination. Antihypertensive therapy is usually initiated for systolic blood pressure greater than 160 or diastolic blood pressure greater than 110

questions.text: A 26-year-old G1P0 woman presents for a prenatal visit at 34 weeks’ gestation. She complains of some mild nausea and vomiting over the past 3 days. She has no headache and no visual changes. Her BP is 142/83 mm Hg. A urinalysis dip has +1 protein The laboratory test results come back with elevated LFTs, low platelets, a normal hematocrit (Hct), and an elevated LDH. What is next step in her management is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Induction of labor HELLP syndrome is a subtype of preeclampsia with severe features. Patients with HELLP syndrome should be delivered promptly. As maternal and fetal status allow, one can defer delivery in patients with HELLP syndrome for 24 to 48 hours to administer betamethasone. In contrast, patients with preeclampsia with severe features can be expectantly managed until 34 weeks. The patient’s BPs are not severely elevated, so she does not need IV hydralazine or oral nifedipine Delivery is the definitive treatment for HELLP syndrome and should be initiated after maternal stabilization. Timing of Delivery • At 34 weeks, delivery is typically indicated immediately after stabilization: • HELLP syndrome at this stage is associated with worsening maternal and fetal risks if pregnancy continues. • Antenatal corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity are not usually necessary after 34 weeks Mode of Delivery • Vaginal Delivery: • Preferred if the cervix is favorable, and maternal and fetal conditions are stable. • Induction of labor can be attempted if it is expected to proceed quickly. • Cesarean Delivery: • Indicated for: • Non-reassuring fetal status. • Severe maternal complications. • Unfavorable cervix or failure to progress.

choices.text: Plan for induction of labor with amniotomy and Pitocin
Prepare for emergent cesarean section because the patient is eclamptic
Lower the patient’s blood pressure with hydralazine
Begin magnesium sulfate intravenously to prevent recurrent seizures

questions.text: A 39-year-old G1P0 at 39 weeks gestational age presents to gynae casualty because she is developing a headache. As you and the nurse enter the room, you witness the patient undergoing a tonic-clonic seizure. You secure the patient’s airway, and within a few minutes the seizure is over. The patient’s blood pressure monitor indicates a pressure of 160/110. You glance over at the fetal heart rate tracing and notice a bradycardia down to the sixties. All of the following are appropriate next steps in the management of this patient except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) First Measure in the Management of Eclampsia The first and most critical measure in the management of eclampsia (the occurrence of seizures in a woman with preeclampsia) is to: 1. Stabilize the Airway, Breathing, and Circulation (ABC Approach) • Airway: • Ensure the airway is patent to prevent aspiration and maintain oxygenation. • Position the patient in the left lateral position to reduce the risk of aspiration and improve venous return. • Breathing: • Administer oxygen via mask if oxygen saturation is low (12/min), and urine output (>30 mL/hour). 3. Control Severe Hypertension • Use antihypertensive medications to reduce blood pressure and prevent complications like stroke: • Labetalol: 20 mg IV bolus, repeated every 10–20 minutes (up to 300 mg total). • Hydralazine: 5–10 mg IV bolus every 20 minutes as needed. • Nifedipine: 10–20 mg orally every 20–30 minutes. 4. Plan for Delivery • Delivery is the definitive treatment for eclampsia and preeclampsia. • Once the patient is stabilized, assess maternal and fetal conditions to determine the safest mode and timing of delivery. • If the fetus is viable and the maternal condition allows, vaginal delivery is preferred. • Cesarean section is indicated if rapid delivery is needed or vaginal delivery is contraindicated.

questions.text: A 32 year old primi presents at 30 weeks because of 10 day history of decreased appetite, intermittent nausea and itching. Her pulse is 98/min and BP 104/64mmhg. The uterus is 30 weeks and lab investigations are as follows Hb 11gm, TLS 11,200/mm3, total bil-2.1, ALP 206, AST 30, ALT26 which of the following is most likely explanation for her symptoms
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP). Key Points Supporting the Diagnosis: 1. Symptoms: • Intermittent nausea and itching are hallmark symptoms of ICP. • Itching, especially on the palms and soles, is the most common symptom and occurs without a rash. 2. Laboratory Findings: • Total Bilirubin: Elevated to 2.1 mg/dL, which is consistent with mild cholestasis. • Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP): Elevated at 206 U/L, a common finding in pregnancy due to placental ALP production. • AST (30 U/L) and ALT (26 U/L): Normal or mildly elevated, which is typical of ICP. Severe transaminitis is uncommon in this condition. 3. Timing: • ICP commonly presents in the third trimester (?30 weeks), aligning with this case. 4. Rule Out Other Options: • AFLP (Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy): • More likely to present with severe nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and profound liver dysfunction (markedly elevated AST/ALT and hypoglycemia). • Total bilirubin is often higher than 5 mg/dL. • HELLP Syndrome: • Associated with hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes (AST/ALT >70 U/L), and thrombocytopenia. • The patient lacks hypertension, proteinuria, and severe transaminitis. • Normal Pregnancy: • Mild ALP elevation can occur in normal pregnancy, but elevated bilirubin (2.1 mg/dL) and itching are not normal findings.

choices.text: Send her to labor and delivery for a BPP.
Admit her to the hospital for enforced bed rest and diuretic therapy to improve her swelling and blood pressure.
Admit her to the hospital for induction of labor
Admit her to the hospital for cesarean delivery

questions.text: A 16-year-old primigravida presents to your o?ce at 38 weeks gestation. Her ?rst trimester blood pressure was 100/72. Today it is 170/110 mm Hg and she has 4+ proteinuria on a clean catch specimen of urine. She has signi?cant swelling of her face and extremities. She denies having contractions. Her cervix is closed and une?aced. The baby is breech by bedside ultrasonography. She says the baby’s movements have decreased in the past 24 hours. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hypertension is diagnosed in pregnancy when the resting blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg or greater. The paent may have a history of chronic hypertension. Gestational hypertension is diagnosed if the patient develops hypertension without proteinuria during the pregnancy. Preeclampsia is diagnosed when the hypertension is associated with proteinuria of greater than 300 mg in a 24 hour collection or persistent 2+ proteinuria in random urine sampling. The treatment for gestational hypertension and preeclampsia is delivery. Select preterm patients may be managed conservatively at home or in the hospital depending upon the severity of the hypertension. BPP testing is useful when following the patient conservatively. Although bed rest may transiently improve elevated blood pressure, a patient at full term should be delivered. Based on the severity of this patient’s blood pressure and the 4+ proteinuria, she has severe preeclamsia and she should be delivered. Since this patient’s fetus is breech, cesarean delivery rather than induction of labor is the next best step in her management. Diuretics should not be used in the management of preeclampsia, as they deplete the maternal intravascular volume and may compromise placental perfusion

questions.text: A patient had BP of 110/72mmhg on her first prenatal visit at 8 weeks, she then develops hypertension in third trimester and her BP is 148/94mmhg. Urine protein by dipstick is 1+ and serum creatinine is 0.76. what is her correct diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gestational Hypertensive patients have only increased blood pressures without proteinuria or other features of preeclampsia. Up to 1/3 of those who are thought to have gestational hypertension are later found to have preeclampsia. Preeclampsia is characterized by hypertension and proteinuria; less commonly, there is absence of proteinuria but evidence of vasospastic disease via other end organ manifestations. Although not a criterion, nondependent oedema is also usually present. An elevated blood pressure is diagnosed with a systolic blood pressure at or >140 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure at or >90 mm Hg. Two elevated BPs, measured 4 hours apart (BP taken in the seated position), are needed for the formal diagnosis of preeclampsia, although at term, presumptive diagnoses with persistent hypertension over a shorter interval often guides management. Proteinuria is usually based on timed urine collection, defined as equal to or greater than 300 mg of protein in 24 hours, although a P/Cr ratio ?0.3 is accurate

questions.text: A 36-year-old G1P0 at 35 weeks gestation presents to labor and delivery complaining of a several-day history of generalized malaise, anorexia, nausea, and emesis. She denies any headache or visual changes. On physical examination, you notice that she is mildly jaundiced and appears to be a little confused. Her vital signs indicate a temperature of 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse of 70 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 100/62 mm Hg. Blood is drawn and the following results are obtained: WBC 25K, Hct 42, platelets 52000, SGOT/PT 287/350, glucose 43 s, serum ammonia 90mmol/l . Urinalysis is positive for 3+ protein and large ketones. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute fay liver of pregnancy is a rare complication of pregnancy. Estimates of its incidence range from 1 in 7000 to 1 in 15,000 pregnancies. This disorder is usually fatal for both mother and baby. Recently, it has been suggested that recessively inherited mitochondrial abnormalities of fatty acid oxidation predispose a woman to fay liver in pregnancy. This disorder usually manifests itself late in pregnancy and is more common in nulliparous women. Typically, a patient will present with a several-day or -week history of general malaise, anorexia, nausea, emesis, and jaundice. Liver enzymes are usually not elevated above 500. Indications of liver failure are present, manifested by elevated PT/PTT, bilirubin, and ammonia levels. In addition, there is marked hypoglycemia. Low fibrinogen and platelet levels occur secondary to a consumptive coagulopathy. In cases of viral hepatitis, serum transaminase levels are usually much higher and marked hypoglycemia or elevated serum ammonia levels would not be seen. Sometimes the HELLP syndrome can inially be di?cult to differentiate from acute fatty liver, but in this case the patient has a normal blood pressure. In addition, hepatic failure is not characteristic of severe preeclampsia. Hyperemesis gravidarum is characterized by nausea and vomiting unresponsive to simple therapy. It usually occurs early in the ?rst trimester and resolves by about 16 weeks. In some cases, there can be a transient hepatic dysfunction. Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is characterized by pruritus and/or icterus. Some women develop cholestasis in the third trimester secondary to estrogen-induced changes. There is an accumulation of serum bile salts, which causes pruritus. Liver enzymes are seldom elevated above 250 U/L

choices.text: Vascular sensitivity to Angiotensin 2 is increased
There is an increase in sFlt1 levels
Decrease in level of soluble endoglin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding pathogenesis of Pre-eclampsia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Explanation: pathogenesis of preeclampsia is characterised by 1. Decreased Angiogenic peptides 2. Increase" soluble endoglin not decrease Both results in hypoxia at placental level Increased sensitivity of angiotensin-2 & depressed angiotensinase activity both cause increased vasoconstriction Decrease soluble endoglin cause decrease in No mediated vasodilation Increase sflt-1 causes decrease in VEGF which impairs angiogenesis

questions.text: Which of the following is doc for controlling bp in patient with severe preeclampsia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Drug of Choice for Hypertension in Preeclampsia The drug of choice for managing hypertension in preeclampsia is Labetalol, as it is safe, effective, and well-tolerated during pregnancy. Why Labetalol is Preferred 1. Mechanism: • A combined alpha- and beta-blocker, Labetalol lowers blood pressure by reducing both peripheral vascular resistance and heart rate. 2. Rapid Onset: • Effective in acute control of severe hypertension. 3. Safety: • Minimal adverse effects on uteroplacental blood flow, making it safe for the fetus. Contraindications 1. Asthma or Bronchospasm: • Risk of beta-2 blockade exacerbating symptoms. 2. Heart Block or Severe Bradycardia: • Due to beta-blocking effects. 3. Decompensated Heart Failure: • Risk of worsening cardiac function. Other Antihypertensive Options 1. Nifedipine • Type: Calcium channel blocker. • Use: Second-line option or combined with labetalol for additional control. • Form: • Immediate-release for acute control (10–20 mg orally). • Sustained-release for chronic management. 2. Hydralazine • Type: Vasodilator. • Use: Acute severe hypertension (SBP ?160 or DBP ?110 mmHg). • Limitations: • Risk of reflex tachycardia. • Associated with maternal hypotension and fetal distress. 3. Methyldopa • Use: First-line for chronic hypertension in pregnancy, but less effective in acute preeclampsia. • Limitations: Slow onset of action, not suitable for emergencies.

questions.text: Which antihypertensive medication is commonly used in the acute management of severe preeclampsia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Labetalol Labetalol is a first-line agent commonly used in the acute management of severe preeclampsia due to its effectiveness, rapid onset, and safety profile in pregnancy. It is a combined alpha- and beta-blocker, which reduces systemic vascular resistance without significantly decreasing heart rate or cardiac output. Labetalol can be administered intravenously, making it ideal for rapid blood pressure control in acute settings. This is especially critical in severe preeclampsia to prevent complications such as stroke, placental abruption, and eclampsia. Its favorable maternal and fetal safety profile makes it one of the preferred agents, alongside hydralazine and oral nifedipine in some cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for immediate delivery in preeclampsia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Persistent headache and vomiting Persistent headache and vomiting in a patient with preeclampsia are signs of severe disease and potential central nervous system involvement, which are absolute indications for immediate delivery, regardless of gestational age. These symptoms may indicate impending eclampsia, cerebral edema, or stroke, all of which pose life-threatening risks to both mother and fetus. According to clinical guidelines, the presence of severe features (e.g., severe hypertension, persistent neurologic symptoms, visual disturbances, or signs of organ damage) necessitates prompt delivery to prevent further maternal and fetal complications. Delaying delivery in such scenarios can result in seizure, hemorrhagic stroke, or death

questions.text: Which angiogenic imbalance is implicated in the pathogenesis of preeclampsia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Increased soluble fms-like tyrosine Increased soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1 (sFlt-1) The pathogenesis of preeclampsia is closely linked to angiogenic imbalance, particularly an increase in soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1 (sFlt-1), an anti-angiogenic factor. sFlt-1 acts as a decoy receptor that binds and neutralizes vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and placental growth factor (PlGF)—key proteins involved in angiogenesis and maintenance of endothelial health. By sequestering these pro-angiogenic factors, sFlt-1 disrupts normal placental vascular development and induces widespread endothelial dysfunction, which is a hallmark of preeclampsia. This imbalance contributes to hypertension, proteinuria, and organ damage, as the maternal vasculature becomes increasingly constricted and leaky. Elevated levels of sFlt-1 in maternal circulation are also used as biomarkers for diagnosis and risk stratification in preeclampsia.

questions.text: 32-year-old woman with severe preeclampsia at 34 weeks is being prepared for delivery. Which of the following is an indication for immediate cesarean section instead of induction of labor?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Non-reassuring fetal heart rate tracing A non-reassuring fetal heart rate (FHR) tracing is an urgent indication for immediate cesarean delivery, especially in the context of severe preeclampsia. FHR abnormalities such as persistent late decelerations, minimal variability, or prolonged bradycardia suggest fetal hypoxia or acidosis, indicating that the fetus may not tolerate labor. In such cases, attempting induction of labor could delay necessary intervention and further jeopardize fetal well-being. Cesarean section is the fastest and safest way to deliver the fetus in this setting, minimizing the risk of perinatal morbidity and mortality. Therefore, fetal status is a critical factor in determining the mode and urgency of delivery in preeclamptic patients.

questions.text: Which first-trimester screening test is most useful in predicting early-onset preeclampsia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Uterine artery Doppler Uterine artery Doppler is the most useful test in predicting early-onset preeclampsia, especially in the first trimester. It assesses the resistance to blood flow in the uterine arteries, which are responsible for supplying blood to the placenta. In patients at risk for preeclampsia, abnormal Doppler findings—such as increased resistance (elevated pulsatility index or PI) and notching in the early part of pregnancy—are associated with poor placental perfusion, which is a key factor in the development of preeclampsia. Early detection using uterine artery Doppler allows for closer monitoring and potential interventions, such as aspirin therapy, which can help prevent the development of the disease in high-risk individuals

choices.text: Bed rest in the second trimester

questions.text: Which intervention has NOT been proven to reduce the risk of preeclampsia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bed rest in the second trimester Bed rest in the second trimester has not been proven to reduce the risk of preeclampsia. Although bed rest was once commonly recommended for managing preeclampsia or preventing its development, studies have shown that it does not offer any significant benefit. Bed rest does not improve maternal or fetal outcomes and can lead to other complications such as muscle atrophy, venous thromboembolism, and mental health effects like anxiety and depression. As a result, bed rest is no longer recommended for the prevention or treatment of preeclampsia, and more effective interventions, such as low-dose aspirin, are preferred.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida at 34 weeks’ gestation is brought to the emergency department after experiencing a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. On arrival, her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg, and she is confused but arousable. Physical examination shows no focal neurological deficits. Urine dipstick reveals 3+proteinuria. What is the most appropriate first step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) IV MgSO4 The most appropriate first step in the management of this patient is IV magnesium sulfate (MgSO4), as she is presenting with eclampsia, which is defined as seizures in a pregnant woman with preeclampsia. Magnesium sulfate is the first-line treatment to prevent further seizures and protect the mother from serious complications like stroke or brain injury. The high blood pressure (170/110 mmHg) and 3+ proteinuria indicate severe preeclampsia, and the seizure is a sign that the condition has progressed to eclampsia. MgSO4 helps to stabilize the neurological status of the patient by acting as a CNS depressant. After stabilizing the patient with magnesium sulfate, blood pressure control and other supportive treatments will follow

choices.text: Start antihypertensive therapy and re-evaluate in 24 hours
Transfuse platelets and schedule cesarean section at 37 weeks
Administer IV corticosteroids and delay delivery

questions.text: Q-8. A 32-year-old G2P1 woman at 36 weeks’ gestation presents with severe right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and headache. Her blood pressure 158/100 mmHg, and she has 3+ proteinuria on urine dipstick. Laboratory results show: • Hemoglobin: 9.2 g/dL• Platelets: 80,000/µL• AST: 210 U/L, ALT: 190 U/L• Total bilirubin: 2.1 mg/sL• LDH: 600 U/LWhich of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Immediate delivery This patient presents with severe preeclampsia complicated by HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelets), which is a life-threatening condition requiring immediate delivery. The right upper quadrant pain, nausea, headache, and laboratory abnormalities (low platelets, elevated AST/ALT, elevated LDH, and elevated bilirubin) strongly suggest HELLP syndrome, a severe form of preeclampsia that can progress rapidly to hepatic rupture, placental abruption, and renal failure if left untreated. The definitive treatment for HELLP syndrome is delivery of the fetus and placenta, regardless of gestational age. Given that this patient is at 36 weeks, delivery should not be delayed, as the risks to both mother and fetus outweigh the benefits of prolonging the pregnancy

choices.text: Administer magnesium sulfate and induce labor
Give corticosteroids and delay delivery until 37 weeks

questions.text: A-30-year-old primigravida at 35 weeks’ gestation presents with severe headache, visual disturbances, and a blood pressure of 170/110 mmHg. Laboratory tests show proteinuria, normal platelets, and normal liver enzymes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Administer magnesium sulfate and induce labor This patient presents with severe preeclampsia at 35 weeks gestation, evidenced by severe hypertension (170/110 mmHg), proteinuria, and symptoms of headache and visual disturbances. The most appropriate next step is to administer magnesium sulfate to prevent seizures (eclampsia), which is the primary concern in patients with severe preeclampsia. In addition to magnesium sulfate, labor should be induced, as the only definitive treatment for preeclampsia is delivery of the fetus and placenta. Given that the patient is at 35 weeks, induction of labor is appropriate to minimize maternal and fetal complications associated with prolonged pregnancy in the presence of severe preeclampsia.

choices.text: Antihypertensive therapy and waiting for spontaneous resolution

questions.text: The best initial management of a patient with severe HELLP syndrome at >34 weeks gestation is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Magnesium sulfate and immediate delivery The best initial management of severe HELLP syndrome at >34 weeks gestation is magnesium sulfate to prevent seizures (eclampsia) and immediate delivery of the fetus and placenta. HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelets) is a severe manifestation of preeclampsia that carries significant maternal and fetal risks, including liver rupture, renal failure, and placental abruption. At >34 weeks, the risks of continued pregnancy outweigh the benefits, and delivery is the definitive treatment for HELLP syndrome. Magnesium sulfate is given to prevent seizures, which are a common complication of severe preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome.

questions.text: The classic presentation of AFLP includes all of the following except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Severe proteinuria The classic presentation of acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) typically does not include severe proteinuria. While proteinuria is commonly seen in preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome, it is not a hallmark feature of AFLP. AFLP is characterized by liver dysfunction leading to jaundice, elevated transaminases, and hypoglycemia, which are the key signs and symptoms. Severe proteinuria is not typically a part of the clinical picture, making it the correct exception in this case

questions.text: A distinguishing feature of AFLP compared to HELLP syndrome is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Severe coagulopathy and hypoglycemia A distinguishing feature of acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) compared to HELLP syndrome is the presence of severe coagulopathy and hypoglycemia. AFLP often causes hypoglycemia due to impaired liver function, which leads to an inability to produce adequate glucose. Additionally, coagulopathy (e.g., prolonged PT, aPTT) can develop due to liver dysfunction and impaired clotting factor synthesis. These findings are more characteristic of AFLP than HELLP syndrome, which typically presents with normal or mildly altered coagulation profiles

questions.text: The most common neurological symptom preceding an eclamptic
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Visual disturbances Visual disturbances are the most common neurological symptoms preceding an eclamptic seizure. These disturbances can include blurred vision, spots, scotomas, or even temporary loss of vision. They are thought to occur due to cerebral vasospasm or retinal ischemia that can result from severe hypertension or endothelial dysfunction associated with preeclampsia. Visual disturbances often precede the onset of eclampsia, and are considered one of the warning signs that prompt closer monitoring for potential progression to seizures.

questions.text: Magnesium sulfate is contraindicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Myasthenia gravis Magnesium sulfate is contraindicated in myasthenia gravis due to its neuromuscular blocking effects. Magnesium sulfate acts as a calcium antagonist and can reduce neuromuscular transmission, which may worsen the symptoms of myasthenia gravis—a condition characterized by muscle weakness due to impaired neuromuscular junction function. The use of magnesium sulfate in these patients can lead to severe muscle weakness and respiratory compromise, which makes it dangerous for individuals with myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: Not true about MgSO4 use in ecplamsia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Monitor Mg level routinely It is not necessary to monitor the magnesium level routinely in patients receiving magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) for eclampsia. While magnesium levels can be measured if there is clinical concern for toxicity (e.g., altered mental status, reduced reflexes, respiratory depression), routine monitoring of magnesium levels is not required for every patient. Clinical signs and symptoms, including urine output, deep tendon reflexes, and respiratory rate, are more reliable and practical for assessing magnesium toxicity in this setting.

choices.text: Withhold the next IM maintenance dose because urine output is borderline
Continue with 5 g MgSO₄ IM in alternate buttock
Give IV calcium gluconate as antidote and stop MgSO₄
Switch to continuous IV infusion regimen

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida with eclampsia is started on the Pritchard regimen of magnesium sulfate. She has already received the loading dose (4 g IV + 10 g IM). After 4 hours, she is due for the next maintenance dose. At this time:• Respiratory rate: 18/min• Urine output: 40 mL/hour• Deep tendon reflexes: presentWhat is the appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Continue with 5 g MgSO? IM in alternate buttock Explanation: • Pritchard regimen: o Loading dose: 4 g MgSO? IV (20% solution, over 5 min) + 10 g MgSO? IM (50% solution, 5 g in each buttock). o Maintenance dose: 5 g MgSO? IM every 4 hours in alternate buttocks × 24 hours (after last seizure or after delivery, whichever is later). • Prerequisites before giving each maintenance dose: 1. Respiratory rate ? 12/min 2. Urine output ? 35 mL/hour (? 100 mL in last 4 hours) 3. Deep tendon reflexes present • In this case: o RR = 18 (? acceptable) o UO = 40 mL/hour (? above 30mL/hour) o Reflexes = present (?) ? All criteria met ? proceed with next IM dose. • Antidote (calcium gluconate) is used only if toxicity signs present (absent reflexes, RR <12, oliguria).
